turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about AIDS (computer virus).
turn.1: What was the damage potential of AIDS II?
turn.2: Unlike other generic file infectors, AIDS II was the second known virus to employ what could be called a "corresponding file technique" of infection so that the original target EXE file is never changed.(The original AIDS was the first.)
turn.3: What does the corresponding file technique mean?
turn.4: The virus takes advantage of the DOS feature where if a file exists in both COM and EXE form, the COM file is executed.
turn.5: How can this technique cause damage?
turn.6: When an "infected" file is executed, since a corresponding COM file exists, the COM file containing the viral code is executed.
turn.7: What other techniques did AIDS II use?
turn.8: The virus first locates an uninfected EXE file in the current directory and creates a corresponding (or companion) COM file with the viral code.
turn.10: These COM files will always be 8,064 bytes in length with a file date/time of the date/time of infection.
turn.11: Does the virus rename the file it infects?
turn.12: After creating the new COM file, the virus then plays a loud chiptune note, and displays the following message: AIDS II then spawns to the EXE file that was attempting to be executed in the first place, and the program runs without problem.
